titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: I return to this Book, after an interval of more than six Months; finding it impossible to write in it from day to day during the Session of Congress—when travelling, or with a crippled hand; and having wasted much of the last Summer with imperfect success in the attempt to retrieve by copying the arrears of my last Volume.— This morning William Spear was here; and I had much conversation with him respecting my private affairs here, which are very irksome to me— I promised to go with him to Mount Wollaston, Wednesday afternoon— Schuyler Sampson the Collector of the Customs at Plymouth called here with his niece, on their way to Boston whence they are to return to-morrow. He told me that there had been a design to set up Solomon Lincoln, in opposition to my re-election to Congress for the twelfth Congressional district; but he believed that project was relinquished; Mr Lincoln being a Royal Arch Mason— But he said the election of Governor would be very warmly contested next November— Mrs Quincy junr with her mother Mrs Miller and Miss Abby Quincy visited our Ladies— My Son Charles came out from Boston this afternoon. His wife is yet somewhat indisposed— Mr Cummings came towards Evening, to make enquiries concerning his claim to certain Lands in the State of Ohio— I referred him to Mr William Jackson, who during the last Session of Congress took charge of that business at the desire of the prior claimant, Cummings’s father— My Son returned to Boston this Evening— I paid a visit to my next door neighbour Mr G. W. Beale— Found there, Mr E Price Greenleaf who said that an offer of twenty thousand dollars had been made to his father, for about twenty Acres of his rocks— Mr Beale said an offer had been made to him last year of twenty thousand dollars for his Squantum farm containing about 190 acres— The value of Land has much increased within the last two years, but as yet without benefit to me— I received a second Letter from Mrs Tudor, and from the Commissioner of the Patent Office Henry L. Ellsworth the Indenture of assignment of Charles Lanes patent, recorded in the Office, and I wrote to Solomon Lincoln, to enclose it to him. I looked up in my garden, my seedlings of the present year which are numerous. I write every day; but as yet very unsatisfactorily.

This day commences the fortieth year since I was married in London— And this day last year I began teaching my Grand-daughter Mary Louisa to read the Bible— She began reading one chapter every day, then two—then five of the Book of Psalms, and since then three chapters each day— I read alternately with her, verse and verse, and we read this day at the commencement of the second year the 27th 28th. and 29th. chapters of Isaiah— I read in the same manner with her and her younger Sister Georgiana Frances, the Psalms in the Book of Common Prayer— I adopt this manner of teaching, that they may learn to read by example as well as by precept— There was a gentle moderate rain, which continued nearly throughout the day, with the exception of short excursions to my eastern seminary, my garden and Nursery— I found, on the single seedling black walnut towards the North end of the Nursery, forty or fifty of the same black and striped worm which I have heretofore found, on the black Oaks, Elms and willows. They had strip’d the tree of about half its leaves—eating the whole leaf, but leaving the naked fibre untouched— The tip ends of almost all of my seedling Apples were also covered with aphides, or green lice, which turn into a small black fly, and which upon being rubbed off with the thumb, and finger stain them with a yellowish colour which it takes several successive ablutions
to wash out.— To account for the very slow growth of some of my seedlings, Mr. E. Price Greenleaf says it is because they are in the neighbourhood of Peach trees, which endure no neighbourhood— I received two days since a Letter from George W. Warren and John S. Sleeper, a Committee of the Directors of the Charlestown Lyceum, inviting me to deliver the introductory Lecture of their course for the next Season—sometime in October— I this day answered the Letter, and declined the task— The rest of the day was occupied chiefly in writing. Josiah Adams junr. was here in the evening, and brought a partial estimate of the cost, of a considerable alteration to be made in our dwelling house— That is for the timber and boards: the stone work and labour to be estimated hereafter

I strolled after breakfast this morning into my seminary garden and nursery, and inspected my seedling trees with my new gardener— I care about nothing but my trees— My Nursery although much thinned the last autumn is yet so full that I can plant nothing new there— In one of my Pots I found Strawberry leaves just up in a pot in which I had planted seeds last July— I found also at the gate corner of my eastern seminary a hickory walnut just out of the ground— The proportion of cherry stones which come up is very small— That of ash leaves, also quite scanty— Seeds come best up in boxes or Pots— I had scarcely returned to my Library, when I had a visit from Mr William Lee who now resides at Roxbury, and who told me that Mr John Lowell had written him yesterday, informing him that Mrs Bethune had written from Paris, that she had seen in London, Lee’s son in Law Baron Maltitz, as Russian Minister— He also told me that Maltitz had written a German Tragedy, which had a run of 48 nights of performance at St. Petersburg—and of which he had sent him a copy for me— He likewise mentioned that Mr and Mrs. Bethune had been received with great distinction, by king Louis-Philippe at Paris—owing to two circumstances. First that when Louis Philippe and his brother were in this Country in exile, and with disguised names, John Amory, Mrs Bethune’s eldest brother, had by information from a French Baker, at whose house they boarded, discovered who they were, and tendered them good offices of kindness, and particularly, any pecuniary assistance they might need— This offer they had declined in a Letter expressive of deep and grateful sensibility, and when the Bethune’s went last Spring to Europe, Lee persuaded Mrs Bethune, the youngest Sister of John Amory now deceased to take that Letter with her, and gave her an introduction to the wife of General Bernard, through whom they obtained the means of reproducing to king Louis-Philippe his old Letter— The second circumstance was the name of Bethune, and his lineal descent from Maximilian, the memorable duke of Sully, the minister of Henry of Bourbon—a fact hitherto unknown to me— Lee says that a descendent from Sully being a Protestant emigrated from France to Scotland; and a descendent from him came from Scotland to this Country. Mr Lee who is growing old, and is desoeuvré, proposed to escort the Ladies to Nahant, or elsewhere in the course of the Summer— Charles came out and dined with us, and after dinner, William Spear took us down to Mount Wollaston, and to Germantown This last place is still the Scene of hazardous and doubtful speculation—Fish-flakes—Salt works by evaporation, and a thousand white mulberry trees and of the Chinese murus multicaulis, are the evidences of these undertakings, while a large, wharf for the use of the Stone-cutting business is building at Bents point on the South side of the junction between the river and creek.— On our return we stopped at the
new house which Josiah Adams junr is building for me at Mount Wollaston. A young man named Whiting, who settled in the town last Summer, was at work, and putting up a Stack of chimneys—almost entirely from those of the old house, which have been taken down— The cellar is a very good one, under the whole house, and eight feet deep— After returning I found a Mr Leeds had been here to make enquiries about Stone-quarries, and that judge Davis, and the Revd. Mr Greenwood had paid us an afternoon visit— Mrs Ann Adams, with her daughter Elizabeth, her two Sons, Isaac and Joseph, her sister Mrs Stebbins, and Louisa C. Smith were here at tea and spent the Evening with us—part of us at a rubber of whist.

I went into Boston this morning, with Gillett’s Stage; surrounded by seven women, and two young girls as fellow passengers— The women were coming in, all the way through Milton, Dorchester and Roxbury. One of them had a young robin, in a basket, covered over with a towel, and which she said she would keep in Boston— I alighted at the foot of Winter Street, and went to my Son Charles’s house— His wife came down to me, and said she was perfectly well; but complained of a singing in her ears which she said had been constant since her return from her late excursion— After sitting with me in conversation about a quarter of an hour, she said suddenly she feared she should faint, and asked me to call one of her maids— Two of them came and helped her up to her bed-chamber— The man Servant was sent for Dr Bigelow, and I went immediately to Charles’s Office where I found him, and advised him of his wife’s indisposition, upon which he immediately went home. I went to the Minister Francis Parkman’s; but he was not at home— I then called again at my Son’s house— Charles was there. Dr Bigelow had not been found, but another physician was with Mrs Adams and had administered an emetic— Before I left the House, Charles told me that it had operated, and his wife was relieved. I then called at Mr James H. Foster’s, and saw Mrs Foster and her three daughters. Mary’s health is yet feeble, but improved since last Summer— My next call was at Mr Hallett’s house; and then at his office; where I had conversation with him on the law of libel; the trial of John P. Zenger, and upon his articles in the Daily Advocate, against the decision of Judge Thacher upon a case of libel which is to be retried upon appeal to the Supreme Court of the Commonwealth, next November. Hallett read me a Letter from Richard Rush, enclosing one from the Secretary of State Forsyth to him, urging him to accept the appointment of Agent to recover the Smithsonian bequest— Rush’s Letter manifests much anxiety to have it represented in the Boston Advocate that this was no exception to a sturdy resolution to accept no political office under President Jackson— I told Hallett that I was very glad Mr Rush had received this appointment, believing that he needed it; and that he would faithfully perform its duties— That I differed very widely from Mr Rush’s present politics, and had no sympathy with his fastidious delicacy about accepting Office, under President Jackson— This is the third Office which he has already accepted as appendages to this administration, and I see no distinction of principle between them and others, more permanent and more important— The Meeting of the Historical Society was notified for 12 O’Clock at Noon—and that of the Overseers of Harvard Colleg at half-past twelve— It was near that when I reached the Historical Society Meeting— They were about ballotting for the Election of Members— They voted according to the primitive practice of New-England, with kernels of maize for affirmative, and small white beans for negative votes— I voted for Henry Clay, President Allen of Brunswick College, and Levi Woodbury, as corresponding members, all of whom were elected. I spoke to Mr Jared Sparks, and enquired if he had any documentary information of the early life of the late Mr Madison; but he said he had none— The President of the Society Thomas L. Winthrop invited me to dine, with him at half past two, which I
accepted— I was soon after called out by judge Joseph Hall, who also invited me to dine with him, which I was obliged to decline— I then went to attend the Meeting of the Board of Overseers, but at the gate of the State House met President Quincy, Dr Pearce the Secretary of the Board, Mr Frothingham, Dr Thomas Gray, and Mr Francis Parkman. The Meeting was over and had confirmed all the honorary Doctorates proposed by the Corporation; among them was N. L. Frothingham as Doctor of Divinity and Levi Woodbury as Doctor of Laws— I spoke to Mr Parkman about the record of Mrs Tudor’s marriage, and promised to call upon him between 4 and 5 in the afternoon— I returned to Charles’s House— Mrs Frothingham was there; and Mr Frothingham to whom I had mentioned Mrs Charles’s sudden illness— Mr P. C. Brooks came in soon after— She was much relieved— At half past two I went and dined with Mr Winthrop— His two Sons; his unmarried daughter, Chief Justice Shaw, Judge White of Salem, Dr. Charles Lowell, and Dr. Gamaliel Bradford were the company I talked more than my share, and not very wisely— Between four and five I went again to Mr Francis Parkman’s, and received from him the extract from the record of his Church, of the marriage of William Tudor with Delia Jarvis on the 5th. of March 1778. by Dr Andrew Eliot then the Pastor of the New North Church— I returned once more to my Son Charles’s House, and then waited for Wilson who had gone in after dinner with the Carriage— I came out alone and got home at the dusk of Evening— The sudden illness of Mrs Charles, cast a gloom over the day, and made my visit to Boston more unpleasant than usual

A long morning wasted upon my Seminary, Nursery, and Garden Seedlings. I found several hickory seedlings just now coming up, in the border from the Summer house cellar to the road— The vegetation of this plant is three months later than that of most of the other seeds. Is not this the reason of its suffering so much from the winter’s frost and when it does not wholly perish, dying down for many years successively to the ground? Might not cracking the nut before planting it cause it to come up earlier in the Spring? an experiment to be made— My other remark this day, is upon the multitude of seedling elms coming up, which must have been self sown, last Spring, and there is one coming up from a remnant of root left from one of those transplanted from the North-end of the Nursery last fall— Mr E. Price Greenleaf was here yesterday and budded for mecherry trees.— Three only of those which he budded last year have succeeded; one of which was transplanted and is now in the seminary lot— The patches which I opened before the embankment, in the border, and between the old Pear trees, to take their places, as they decay, are now all stocked with seedlings of the last or the present year, and those in front of my library window, seedling apples, pears and peaches of 1834. and 1835 are as thrifty as I could expect— Louisa C. Smith was here before dinner and Joseph H. Adams, who said he had been at my Son Charles’s house last Evening and was told that his wife had been very sick and was no better. This made us so uneasy that my wife went into Boston this afternoon, and returned with the Evening Bell; she found Mrs Charles much recovered, but not well enough to come out to Quincy to-morrow— Charles was gone to Medford to dine at Mr P. C. Brooks’s. My remnant of morning was absorbed by this diary; after dinner I wrote a page and a half, but the rest of the time escaped in a search to follow the Articles of Confederation in their progress through Congress from June 1776 to 1. March 1781. which search was left unfinished at the dusk. Mrs Giusta arrived here from Washington— Her husband
Antoine Michel, instead of going as he intended to France, to visit his family, is gone to Michigan to speculate in Lands— Mr William Jackson, the member of Congress, and his brother Francis Jackson were also here this afternoon— Francis Jackson is one of the company who are now building the wharf at Bent’s point— They asked me many questions about the Stone quarries, of which they know much more than I— At the dusk of Evening I walked to the sixth Milestone, that I might peradventure meet my wife returning from Boston—but she came home later— I wrote, and enclosed her certificate to Mrs Tudor.

The Midshipman was here this morning to enquire for Letters. Coll. Quincy’s Son, Josiah, brought me a note, inviting me to tea, at his house this Evening. There is a fascination at this Season of the year in my garden, nursery and seminary which I am seldom able to resist—and which absorbs hour after hour of precious time in mere useless gazing at seedling trees. I mark my seedling plums, which are one in the Seminary, of this year, two of 1835, and two of 1834. in the garden; and at the root of one of the last I found an Ant’s nest— The leaves of my maple trees, are much devoured by insects, which checks very much their growth. There is matter for observation upon the variety of the manner in which the trees present themselves as they first come out of the ground— The Oak and the Walnut open their leaves in no uniform manner— The Apple and cherry sometimes put up their seed leaves above the surface; and sometimes do not— When the seed leaves come out, the tree is more liable to be destroyed— There is a mass of observations upon the vegetation of plants, which accumulate from year to year, but which remain barren upon my mind, for want of an active reasoning faculty, to be applied to them—every natural phenomenon has its cause and its effect. The phenomenon is first to be observed. Then traced to its cause—then followed to its effect; all of which requires continuance of observation, and then the combining faculty of reason— I have curiosity to observe; but not facility to combine, nor ingenuity to devise— Of the remnant of this day I squandered much in tracing through the Journals of the Revolutionary Congress, the progress of the Articles of the Confederation—till I found the whole History of them in the compilation of the Secret Journals of the Old Congress.— I pored and plodded much, and wrote very little— Towards Sunset, I walked to Coll. Quincy’s, and there met his father, mother and Sister Abby, Chief Justice Shaw, Coll. Swett, a Mr M’Cord of South-Carolina, Mr Nathan Hale, and Mr Lunt, with whom and Coll. Quincy’s family, I spent the Evening— Mr Savage was also one of the Company— Mr Hale told me that General Gaines had called out four thousand men of the Militia, of four South and western States, upon allegation of some indian outrage, and with manifestation of a disposition to cross the Sabine river, Mr Savage talked of the man of the Iron Mask, and of Junius: and Mr Quincy of Cotton Mather and the centennial celebration— I walked home, in company, to the parting of the roads, with Mr Lunt— Mrs. Adams had received a note from Charles, whose wife is still so much indisposed that they have postponed her coming out here till Tuesday. May I hope she will be able to come then?

We were so uneasy on account of the health of Charles’s wife that his mother went with Mrs Wilson this morning into Boston and brought out this Evening their two elder children Louisa-Catherine, and John Quincy— At meeting Mr Whitney performed the morning service and preached from 1. Timothy 5.22—“neither be partaker of other men’s sins: keep thyself pure.” This text opens a wide field for commentary; but Mr Whitney considered the subject only as bearing upon the characters of men in private and domestic life— It was however a sensible and edifying discourse.
After meeting, Mr E. Price Greenleaf walked home with me, and looked into my Garden, at two of the Apple trees which were girdled last winter by the field mice— One of them was the most thrifty one of the whole number that I had planted in November 1830. It is now eleven or twelve years old, and for the first time bears fruit— The mice have so completely girdled it, that he thought the tree must die next winter— There are however two new shoots above, and two below the bud, which he thinks may still save it; an experiment of which I can hardly expect to witness the issue if it should succeed— Elizabeth C. Adams dined with us— Mr Cunningham of Roxbury was the afternoon preacher, from Luke 23.34. “Then said Jesus, father, forgive them, for they know not what they do.”— The discourse was very impressive, and full of excellent moral instruction, but delivered in a lisping manner, much subject to the censure of affectation— I read the 6th. and 7th. Sermons of the 8th. Volume of Saurin, upon Ephesians 5.16. “Redeeming the time”— These are upon the whole the most instructive discourses of the whole collection—and perhaps if I had read them forty years ago, I might have derived some benefit from them— It is now too late— My memory retains nothing that I read; and little of any thing that happens— Saurin’s application of his own doctrine, to the aged, encourages no hope, and freely acknowledges and comments upon the utter impossibility for old men to redeem the time— I felt intensely many parts of these Discourses, but am conscious that without the mercy from above which I invoke they will yet be lost upon me, and that instead of setting my house in order, I shall still not be duly prepared to meet the summons when it comes. I wrote this day very little.

Day— I rise between four and six O’Clock—and after trifling half an hour with time, write my diary, and read the Bible with my two granddaughters, till breakfast between eight and nine— After Breakfast I stroll three hours in my Seminary, Nursery and Garden—read newspapers, receive visitors and write when I can till between two and three— After which I take a Siesta of an hour; write again till the dusk of Evening, and then walk out or spend a couple of hours with my family; retiring about ten O’Clock in the Evening to bed.
